Yes, I've been looking for it and this issue seems not to be addressed anywhere as far as I can tell? Seems like a fundamental question?? Here's the use case:

I'm trying out a purely topological version of fundamental domains. To allow the domain to be as general as possible, I assume that the translates of the closures cover, while the interiors are pairwise disjoint:

structure IsFundamentalDomain (G : Type _) {Œ± : Type _} [One G] [SMul G Œ±] [TopologicalSpace Œ±]
    (s : Set Œ±) : Prop where
  protected covers : (‚ãÉ g : G, closure (g ‚Ä¢ s)) = univ
  protected disjoint : Pairwise <| (Disjoint on fun g : G ‚Ü¶ interior (g ‚Ä¢ s))

(I'm renaming the old IsFundamentalDomain to IsAEFundamentalDomain, as @Yury G. Kudryashov suggested. We'll see if this experiment works out...)

Then I define, for a MetricSpace, a DirichletPolyhedron (for which it's useful to have "DirichletSet"s isolated):

variable (G : Type _) [Group G] [Countable G] {Œ± : Type _} [MetricSpace Œ±] [MulAction G Œ±]

def DirichletSet (x : Œ±) (g : G) : Set Œ± := { y : Œ± | dist x y ‚â§ dist (g ‚Ä¢ x) y }

def DirichletPolyhedron (x : Œ±) : Set Œ± := ‚ãÇ g : G, DirichletSet G x g

I'm able to prove that these indeed cover. (It's nontrivial; quite fun actually, first year grad stuff...)

theorem IsCover_of_DirichletPolyhedron [ProperSpace Œ±] [i‚ÇÅ : ProperlyDiscontinuousSMul G Œ±]
    (x : Œ±) : ‚ãÉ (g : G), closure (g ‚Ä¢ DirichletPolyhedron G x) = univ := ...
(As you see, I need to assume ProperlyDiscontinuousSMul, as expected. I also need to assume ProperSpace, as it turns out. I have no problems with that.)

The issue comes with pairwise disjointedness:

theorem IsDisjoint_of_DirichletPolyhedron (x : Œ±) (hx : ‚àÄ g : G, g ‚Ä¢ x ‚â† x) : ‚àÄ (g‚ÇÅ g‚ÇÇ : G),
    g‚ÇÅ ‚â† g‚ÇÇ ‚Üí
    Disjoint (interior (g‚ÇÅ ‚Ä¢ DirichletPolyhedron G x)) (interior (g‚ÇÇ ‚Ä¢ DirichletPolyhedron G x))
    :=
Of course now I need to assume that x is not the fixed point of any g : G

If I can prove that, then of course I can conclude that a DirichletPolyhedron is indeed a fundamental domain:

theorem IsFundamentalDomain_of_DirichletPolyhedron [ProperSpace Œ±]
    [i‚ÇÅ : ProperlyDiscontinuousSMul G Œ±] (x : Œ±) (hx : ‚àÄ g : G, g ‚Ä¢ x ‚â† x) :
    IsFundamentalDomain G (DirichletPolyhedron G x) where
      covers := IsCover_of_DirichletPolyhedron G x
      disjoint := IsDisjoint_of_DirichletPolyhedron G x hx

lemma interior_DirichletSet (x : Œ±) (g : G) :
    interior (DirichletSet G x g) = DirichletSet‚ÇÄ G x g := ...?

Ok I think I've gotten to the bottom of this. The condition, which I'm calling ExtendableSpace is a very natural one, it seems to me, and turns out (though maybe it's "obvious") that it's completely equivalent to the question of interior of a closed ball being an open ball: (I added the condition x ‚â† y to avoid nonsense with Nontrivial) 

import Mathlib.Topology.MetricSpace.Basic

open Set
open scoped Topology

structure ExtendableSpace (Œ± : Type _) [PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] : Prop where
  protected extendable : ‚àÄ x y : Œ±, x ‚â† y ‚Üí ‚àÉ·∂† z in ùìù y, dist x y < dist x z

lemma interior_closedBall'' {Œ± : Type _} [PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] {hŒ± : ExtendableSpace Œ±} (x : Œ±)
    (r : ‚Ñù) (hr : r ‚â† 0) : interior (Metric.closedBall x r) = Metric.ball x r := by
  cases' hr.lt_or_lt with hr hr
  ¬∑ rw [Metric.closedBall_eq_empty.2 hr, Metric.ball_eq_empty.2 hr.le, interior_empty]
  refine Subset.antisymm ?_ Metric.ball_subset_interior_closedBall
  intro y hy
  by_cases x_eq_y : x = y
  ¬∑ rw [x_eq_y]
    exact Metric.mem_ball_self hr
  obtain ‚ü®t, ‚ü®t_isOpen, t_in_closedBall‚ü©, y_in_t‚ü© := hy
  have extend := (hŒ±.extendable x y x_eq_y)
  rw [Filter.frequently_iff] at extend
  obtain ‚ü®z, z_in_t, dist_xz‚ü© := extend (IsOpen.mem_nhds t_isOpen y_in_t)
  have z_in_ball : z ‚àà Metric.closedBall x r := mem_of_subset_of_mem t_in_closedBall z_in_t
  rw [Metric.mem_closedBall, dist_comm] at z_in_ball
  rw [Metric.mem_ball, dist_comm]
  linarith

theorem NotMemBallSelf {Œ± : Type _} [PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] (x y : Œ±) :
    ¬¨ y ‚àà Metric.ball x (dist x y) := by
  rw [Metric.mem_ball, dist_comm]
  linarith

lemma Extendable_of_interior_closedBall {Œ± : Type _} [MetricSpace Œ±]
    (h : ‚àÄ x : Œ±, ‚àÄ (r : ‚Ñù), r ‚â† 0 ‚Üí interior (Metric.closedBall x r) = Metric.ball x r) :
    ExtendableSpace Œ± where
      extendable := by
        intro x y x_ne_y
        by_contra hh
        simp_rw [Filter.not_frequently, Filter.eventually_iff, not_lt] at hh
        have ball_in_ùìù : Metric.closedBall x (dist x y) ‚àà ùìù y
        ¬∑ convert hh
          ext z
          simp [Metric.mem_closedBall, Metric.mem_ball, dist_comm, mem_setOf]
        have := interior_mem_nhds.mpr ball_in_ùìù
        rw [h x (dist x y) (ne_of_gt (dist_pos.mpr x_ne_y)), mem_nhds_iff] at this
        obtain ‚ü®t, t_in_ball, -, y_in_t‚ü© := this
        have y_in : y ‚àà Metric.ball x (dist x y) := mem_of_mem_of_subset y_in_t t_in_ball
        exact NotMemBallSelf x y y_in

theorem Extendable_iff_interior_closedBall {Œ± : Type _} [MetricSpace Œ±] :
    ExtendableSpace Œ± ‚Üî
    ‚àÄ x : Œ±, ‚àÄ (r : ‚Ñù), r ‚â† 0 ‚Üí interior (Metric.closedBall x r) = Metric.ball x r :=
  ‚ü®fun i ‚Ü¶ @interior_closedBall'' Œ± _ i, fun h ‚Ü¶ Extendable_of_interior_closedBall h‚ü©

Then one can refactor interior_closedBall by proving that NormedSpaces are Extendable. Sound worthwhile to you all?
